title: 105_s2564
content: The "Ricky Ray Hemophilia Relief Fund Act of 1998" includes provisions for the establishment of the Ricky Ray Hemophilia Relief Fund, compassionate payments, determination and payment processes, limitations on rights transfer and petitions, time limitations, and definitions. It also addresses the treatment of private settlement payments in hemophilia-clotting-factor suits under the Medicaid and SSI programs. The "Ricky Ray Hemophilia Relief Fund Act of 1998" establishes the Ricky Ray Hemophilia Relief Fund. The "Ricky Ray Hemophilia Relief Fund" is established in the Treasury of the United States and administered by the Secretary of the Treasury. Amounts in the Fund are to be invested in accordance with specific regulations, and any interest or proceeds from investments will be credited to the Fund. The Fund will be available for disbursement by the Secretary of Health and Human Services under section 103, and will terminate after a 5-year period from the enactment of the Act. If any amounts remain unexpended, investments will be liquidated, and the proceeds deposited back into the Fund. The remaining funds in the "Ricky Ray Hemophilia Relief Fund" will be deposited into the miscellaneous receipts account in the Treasury of the United States. $1,771,400,000 is authorized to be appropriated to the Fund for implementation of this title. SEC. 102. COMPASSIONATE PAYMENT. Eligible Individuals for a $100,000 payment from the Fund include those with HIV infection or diagnosed with AIDS, and individuals with blood-clotting disorders treated with antihemophilic factor since July 1, 1982. Eligible individuals for a $100,000 payment from the Fund include those with HIV infection or diagnosed with AIDS, individuals with blood-clotting disorders treated with antihemophilic factor since July 1, 1982, and individuals who were exposed to HIV contaminated blood transfusion, blood components, or human tissue between January 1, 1982, and March 31, 1985. Spouses of affected individuals are also eligible for compensation. The conditions for eligibility for a $100,000 payment from the Fund include individuals with HIV infection, blood-clotting disorders treated with antihemophilic factor, and those exposed to HIV contaminated blood products. Spouses of affected individuals are also eligible for compensation. Individuals must submit medical documentation confirming their HIV infection. Individuals eligible for a $100,000 payment from the Fund must have an HIV infection, a blood-clotting disorder like hemophilia treated with antihemophilic factor, or exposure to HIV contaminated blood products. A petition must be filed with the Secretary for payment. The Secretary determines if the petition meets the requirements of this title. SEC. 103. DETERMINATION AND PAYMENT. The Secretary of Health and Human Services establishes filing procedures for petition submissions under this title. Each petition is reviewed to determine if it meets the requirements. Payments are made from the Fund in the order received, with priority given during the initial 180-day period of accepting petitions. The Secretary makes payments to eligible individuals under this title, with priority given during the initial 180-day period. Payments are also made in case of deceased individuals, with specific instructions for surviving spouses. If an individual is not survived by a spouse, the payment will be divided equally among their living children. If there are no surviving spouse or children, the payment will be shared equally among the living parents. If there are no surviving spouse, children, or parents, the payment will be distributed accordingly. If an individual eligible for payment under section 102(a) dies before filing a petition, a survivor may file on their behalf if eligible. Definitions include "spouse" as a lawfully married individual at the time of death, and "child" as a recognized natural or stepchild. The Secretary may not make a payment on a petition under this title before the expiration of the 120-day period beginning on the date of the enactment of this Act or after the expiration of the 5-year period beginning on the date of the enactment of this Act. The Secretary shall complete the determination required by subsection (b) regarding a petition not later than 120 days after the date the petition is filed under this title. The Secretary must not make a payment on a petition before 120 days after filing. For petitions by certain individuals, payment cannot be made before the expiration of a specified period. The Act does not create any claims against the United States related to HIV infection from treatment. Acceptance of payment under the Act settles all claims by or on behalf of the individual. Administrative costs are not paid from the fund. The Secretary's duties under this section will end when the Fund terminates. Payments to individuals under subsection (c)(1) are considered damages for tax purposes and do not affect eligibility for other benefits. The Secretary may issue regulations to implement this title and must establish procedures within 120 days of the Act's enactment. The benefits provided shall not be contingent on reimbursement or subject to recovery, including from the Federal or State governments. SEC. 104. LIMITATION ON TRANSFER OF RIGHTS AND NUMBER OF PETITIONS. Any right under this title shall not be assignable or transferable. With respect to each individual, the Secretary may not make payment for more than 1 petition filed. SEC. 105. TIME LIMITATION. The Secretary may not make any payment for a petition filed under this title after 3 years from the enactment of this Act. SEC. 106. CERTAIN CLAIMS NOT AFFECTED BY PAYMENT. SEC. 106. CERTAIN CLAIMS NOT AFFECTED BY PAYMENT. A payment under this title does not count as compensation or reimbursement for imposing liability on the recipient to repay insurance or worker's compensation. It also does not affect any claims against insurance carriers or persons regarding insurance or worker's compensation. SEC. 107. LIMITATION ON AGENT AND ATTORNEY FEES. Representatives cannot receive more than 5% of the payment under this title for services rendered. Violators may be fined up to $50,000. SEC. 108. DEFINITIONS. TITLE II--TREATMENT OF CERTAIN PAYMENTS IN HEMOPHILIA-CLOTTING-FACTOR SUIT UNDER THE SSI PROGRAM. Definitions: AIDS - acquired immune deficiency syndrome, Fund - Ricky Ray Hemophilia Relief Fund, HIV - human immunodeficiency virus, Secretary - Secretary of Health and Human Services. Private payments from specific settlements or releases are not considered income or resources for determining eligibility for medical assistance or supplemental security income benefits. These payments include those from the Susan Walker v. Bayer Corporation case and releases of claims in certain cases. Private payments from specific settlements or releases, such as those from the Susan Walker v. Bayer Corporation case, are not considered income or resources for determining eligibility for medical assistance or supplemental security income benefits. An alternative class settlement can be signed by all affected parties before December 31, 1997, or within 270 days of the release being sent out. Government payments from the fund established under section 101 of this Act are considered for determining eligibility or the amount of supplemental security income benefits under title XVI of the Social Security Act.
